awd_titl_txt: Development of tunnel field effect optoelectronic devices based on stacked 2D crystals with clean interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:
Optical communication is based on converting electrical signals into optical signals by optoelectronic devices such as lasers and photodiodes. Devices based on conventional semiconductors such as silicon are reaching the ultimate limits for performance. New materials and structures are required to advance the state of the art. The discovery of graphene, a two-dimensional (2D) layer of carbon, shows how new electronic properties emerge when a bulk material is thinned down to a single layer. Other 2D materials include boron nitride, black phosphorous, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Different 2D materials can be assembled one layer at a time into vertically stacked thin films. Such heterostructures can achieve functions and performance not possible with a single material. The interface between different 2D materials is critical to maintaining the unique properties that make them attractive for device applications. The principal investigator will use a newly developed clean-transfer method to prepare 2D heterostructure materials with clean interfaces. A custom-built scanning probe microscope with nanometer-scale light sources at the tip will be used to study the optical and electronic properties of devices with unprecedented resolution.  Results from this project will enrich the understanding of these materials and accelerate the development of nanoscale optoelectronics. This interdisciplinary project will integrate research into education of graduate and undergraduate students in material science, engineering, and nanomanufacturing. This project will also seek to broaden participation in science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

Technical:
This proposal will combine novel 2D-heterostructure material preparation techniques, near-field scanning optics microscopy and near-field scanning photocurrent microscopy to investigate the fundamental optoelectronic properties and photocarrier behaviors in van der Waals material-based heterostructures. The photocurrent imaging with high spatial resolution, below 10nm, can reveal rich physics in nanoscale features. These include local pn-junctions, domain boundaries, edges, dopants, and strains. Imaging such features can significantly improve the understanding and enhance the control of the electronic and photonic properties of this new material system. The objectives of this project are to: (1) demonstrate a prototype tapping-mode near-field scanning photocurrent microscopy to investigate heterostructure devices, (2) improve the spatial resolution of scanning photocurrent imaging technique to sub-10nm level, and (3) study the photoresponsivity of vertically-stacked heterostructures based on graphene, boron nitrides, transmission metal dichalcogenides such as WSe2, MoS2, and MoSe2, and (4) develop fundamental understanding of the roles of nanoscale features, such as edge terminations and interlayer defect formation on the optoelectronic properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has made significant strides in advancing the field of optoelectronics through the development of new tunnel field-effect optoelectronic devices utilizing stacked 2D crystals with pristine interfaces. One of the project’s most noteworthy achievements was the development of 3D photocurrent near-field microscopy with 4-nm spatial resolution and the development of a Schottky photodiode at the interface between 2D heterostructures and a gold electrode, which demonstrated highly efficient photocurrent generation dominated by the photothermoelectric (PTE) effect, rather than the traditional photovoltaic (PV) effect.

Intellectual Merit: 

Central to the project’s achievements was the development of a Schottky photodiode utilizing an interface between 2D heterostructures and gold electrodes, which demonstrated an unprecedented efficiency in photocurrent generation primarily driven by the photothermoelectric (PTE) effect. This effect proved more substantial than the photovoltaic effects traditionally relied upon in similar devices, significantly advancing our understanding of photocurrent mechanisms and serving as a pivotal enhancement for nanoscale device engineering. This discovery influences future designs and applications in the semiconductor industry, particularly in the development of integrated optoelectronics and electronics. The project’s novel 3D photocurrent NSOM (Near-field Scanning Optical Microscopy) has revolutionized our capability to examine light-matter interactions at the nanoscale. This cutting-edge tool allows for the precise mapping and analysis of photocurrent distributions within nanostructured devices, offering new insights into carrier behaviors, electron-phonon interactions, and the intricate dynamics of electronic transport at nanoscale dimensions. The in-plane PTE effect, discovered during this study, highlights the increased thermal gradients crucial for the operation of integrated optoelectronic devices, providing a deeper understanding and potential improvements in device performance and efficiency. Contributions from this project also extended to the development of super-resolution optical transmission and scattering spectroscopic imaging technique, utilizing a nanometer-scale white light source. This innovation has opened new pathways for probing material properties at scales previously unachievable, expanding our capacity to study the atomic-level interactions and behaviors in novel materials. Additionally, advancements such as high external-efficiency nanofocusing for lens-free near-field optical nanoscopy and the innovative design of photonic-plasmonic nanodevices guided by physics-informed neural networks have pioneered new methods for manipulating light at the nanoscale and enhancing device functionalities across various applications. These technologies not only improve our fundamental understanding of optical phenomena but also contribute to the development of advanced manufacturing techniques and applications in fields ranging from data storage to integrated circuitry. The project’s emphasis on developing high-efficiency nanofocusing techniques represents a major stride towards bridging the gap between macroscopic optical systems and nanoscale photonic devices, enabling precise assembly of fluorescent nanodiamonds on probe tips, which enhances photoluminescence intensity and signal-to-noise ratios. Near the end of the support, the project focuses on advancing quantum imaging applications using optically detected magnetic resonance (ODMR). Through its comprehensive and innovative approach, the project continues to foster significant scientific breakthroughs that enhance our ability to design, understand, and manipulate electronic and photonic systems at the nanoscale.

Broader Impacts:

The broader impacts of this research are vast and varied, touching upon multiple disciplines and potentially revolutionizing the design and functionality of integrated optoelectronics. The insights gained from studying the in-plane PTE effect underscore the importance of thermal management in device architecture, especially as devices continue to shrink in size while increasing in complexity and functionality. By understanding and controlling the thermal gradients and photocurrent responses at the nanoscale, this project paves the way for the development of more efficient, compact, and faster electronic and photonic devices, thereby benefiting a wide array of technologies from high-speed computing to sensitive environmental sensors. Additionally, the methodologies and nanotechnologies developed here have implications beyond traditional electronics, impacting fields such as quantum computing and advanced diagnostic tools, where precise control over electronic and optical properties is crucial. The 3D photocurrent NSOM developed in this project not only serves the scientific community by providing a sophisticated tool for detailed materials characterization but also acts as a bridge linking fundamental scientific research with practical technological applications. The project has set new standards for the exploration of optoelectronic materials and devices at the nanoscale, expanding theoretical frameworks and broader impacts by applying this new knowledge to solve practical problems in technology development.

In conclusion, this project has made substantial contributions to the fundamental understanding of nanoscale phenomena in optoelectronics and photonics, setting the stage for innovations that could transform a range of technologies. It has enriched the scientific community’s understanding of material interfaces and the critical role of thermal and electronic interactions in device performance, establishing a strong foundation for the next generation of technological advancements in nanoscale device engineering.
